data.title: Catalog
data.meta_description: Frankie Ware, an American author living in Paris, eases the dying moments of a young girl named Alice Ellery, who has just given birth to an illegitimate child. Frankie adopts the child and returns to New York, where she writes a book questioning the one-sided social laws that make this a man's world. Her publisher, Malcolm Gaskell, falls in love with her, and the two become engaged, but Frankie's rival, Lione Brune, attempts to destroy the romance by jealously suggesting that "Kiddie" is Frankie's child. Angrily, Malcolm rushes to Frankie's apartment and demands to know the truth, whereupon Frankie, noticing the resemblance between Kiddie and Malcolm, asks him if he ever met Alice Ellery in Paris. When he betrays his own guilt, Frankie breaks the engagement and later marries David Powell, who has loved her all along.
data.text:
Principal photography was underway by late May 1918, according to a news brief in the 25 May 1918 Motion Picture News. An Ida May Park film also produced in spring 1918 shared the title A Man’s World; however, that picture’s title was revised to The Model’s Confession (see entry) prior to release.

This picture opened on 24 June 1918. Reviews in the 29 June 1918 Motion Picture News and 5 July 1918 Variety were largely negative.

Wid's Daily credited the photography to George K. Hollister, while Variety named Ernest Palmer as the photographer.

The National Film Preservation Board (NFPB) included the picture on its list of Lost U.S. Silent Feature Films as of February 2021. ...

More Less

Principal photography was underway by late May 1918, according to a news brief in the 25 May 1918 Motion Picture News. An Ida May Park film also produced in spring 1918 shared the title A Man’s World; however, that picture’s title was revised to The Model’s Confession (see entry) prior to release.

This picture opened on 24 June 1918. Reviews in the 29 June 1918 Motion Picture News and 5 July 1918 Variety were largely negative.

Wid's Daily credited the photography to George K. Hollister, while Variety named Ernest Palmer as the photographer.

The National Film Preservation Board (NFPB) included the picture on its list of Lost U.S. Silent Feature Films as of February 2021.

Less

Frankie Ware, an American author living in Paris, eases the dying moments of a young girl named Alice Ellery, who has just given birth to an illegitimate child. Frankie adopts the child and returns to New York, where she writes a book questioning the one-sided social laws that make this a man's world. Her publisher, Malcolm Gaskell, falls in love with her, and the two become engaged, but Frankie's rival, Lione Brune, attempts to destroy the romance by jealously suggesting that "Kiddie" is Frankie's child. Angrily, Malcolm rushes to Frankie's apartment and demands to know the truth, whereupon Frankie, noticing the resemblance between Kiddie and Malcolm, asks him if he ever met Alice Ellery in Paris. When he betrays his own guilt, Frankie breaks the engagement and later marries David Powell, who has loved her all ...

More Less

Frankie Ware, an American author living in Paris, eases the dying moments of a young girl named Alice Ellery, who has just given birth to an illegitimate child. Frankie adopts the child and returns to New York, where she writes a book questioning the one-sided social laws that make this a man's world. Her publisher, Malcolm Gaskell, falls in love with her, and the two become engaged, but Frankie's rival, Lione Brune, attempts to destroy the romance by jealously suggesting that "Kiddie" is Frankie's child. Angrily, Malcolm rushes to Frankie's apartment and demands to know the truth, whereupon Frankie, noticing the resemblance between Kiddie and Malcolm, asks him if he ever met Alice Ellery in Paris. When he betrays his own guilt, Frankie breaks the engagement and later marries David Powell, who has loved her all along.

Less
